_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: East and West ammonia tanks inspection

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia (MEAG), headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia, is a public generation and transmission company that provides power to almost 50 communities in Georgia.  The company owns a natural gas combined cycle combustion turbine facility at the Wansley Power Plant in Heard County, Georgia.  This facility, Wansley Unit 9, maintains a site specific accident prevention program and an emergency response plan.  The facility coordinates its emergency response plan with power plants located in close proximity.  Regulatory compliance issues that apply to the site are managed by MEAG and its facility operator.  



2.    The Facility and the Regulated Substances Handled



Wansley Unit 9 is located south of Lowell, Georgia, close to the Northwest corner of Heard County.  Unit 9 consists of two natural gas fired combustion turbines each feeding a Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG).  Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) systems have been installed to decrease nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions that are produced by the turbines.   Anhydrous ammonia is used in the SCR process to reduce the NOx to nitrogen and water.  Wansley Unit 9 stores liquefied anhydrous ammonia in two 15,000 gallon tanks for addition to the SCR process.  

Although each ammonia vessel has a total capacity of 15,000 gallons, the facility Ammonia Unloading Procedure limits the tank level to 80% of capacity, or a maximum inventory in each tank of 12,000 gallons.  The total process inventory of anhydrous ammonia is therefore 123,600 lbs. of ammonia, which exceeds the 10,000 lb. threshold quantity for RMP.  



3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The RMP regulation requires the classification of each process into Program Level 1, 2, or 3 in order to determine the prevention program requirements.  Since the worst case release scenario would impact a public receptor, the process

cannot be classified as a Program 1.  Program 3 processes are ones that are not Program 1, but are subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard, 29 CFR 1910.119, or one of the 10 NAICS codes listed in the RMP Rule.  The Wansley Unit 9 SCR process will use the PSM Program as the required Program 3 Prevention Program.  

The PSM Program was established in the summer of 2003 prior to facility startup.  Wansley Unit 9's PSM Program receives the full support of plant management and includes involvement of employees and contractors who work on or near the SCR process.

The prevention program consists of the following elements:

Employee Participation:  This program involves employees in establishing and implementing the program.  Employees are also involved when a process hazard analysis (PHA) is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have access to the program.

Process Safety Information: Written information has been collected which enables employees to identify and understand the potential hazards of the system.  The written information includes the Safety Data Sheet for ammonia and a description of the SCR process design.

Process Hazard Analysis:  Qualified plant personnel have conducted studies, using the What-If/Checklist Technique to evaluate the system and identify potential hazards.

Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed to describe the steps that should be followed to safely operate the SCR process.  Procedures cover both normal and emergency conditions.

Training:  A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the SCR process. 

Contractors:  All contractors are evaluated before they perform work on or near the SCR process.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure safe work practices are followed.  

Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review

is completed for all new projects that affect the covered process in order to verify that all safety programs are in place, training has been conducted, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use.

Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the SCR process is built and maintained using preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures. 

Hot Work Permit:  Procedures ensure that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning.

Management of Change:  The procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the SCR process are properly reviewed.

Incident Investigation:  The procedures ensure that any accidents and near misses are investigated, reviewed and documented using an investigation team.

Compliance Audits:  There are procedures to conduct regular audits of the program to ensure the program is in place and working properly.                                                                                                                                                                  



4.    Five-year Accident History



Wansley Unit 9 has had no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years.



5.    Emergency Response Program



Wansley Unit 9 has an emergency response plan in place that complies with 29 CFR 1910.38, 1910.39, and 1910.120.  The plan has been coordinated with the West Georgia Regional Local Emergency Planning Committee at the Carroll County Fire and Rescue & EMA.  Notification is made locally by dialing 911 and by notifying the Georgia Environmental Protection Division of Emergency Operations Center at 1-800-241-4113.



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Wansley Unit 9 is implementing the recommendations from the recent PHA revalidation.
